data.text: The Garmin Rally XC200: Any Alternatives?
Anyone have experience with the garmin rally xc200? Are there really any competitors out there?
I converted Favero Assioma Duo to SPD‚Ä¶

data.text: I‚Äôve seen this conversion on YouTube. Seems easy enough! I‚Äôm just worried about the warranty piece üòÖ

data.text: I don‚Äôt think so‚Ä¶ all the seals, bearings, etc. used are the oem ones. You literally just swap the spindle.

data.text: good point. Any issues with the big spindle part sticker out further than your crank arm and/or hitting stuff?

data.author: Steve Heintzelman

data.text: good to know. Any issues with the big spindle part sticker out further than your crank arm and/or hitting stuff?
data.author: Tyler L. Jenicek

data.text: I only use for gravel and light single track and no issues‚Ä¶ I would definitely use the Garmin version for a full on MTB or if I rode more hardcore stuff
data.author: Steve Heintzelman

data.text: I have both. Converted the Assiomas myself. Only conversion issue was a shim that was a little too thick. Sanded it down and they work well. I did have to carve a few of my cycling shoes soles to clear the body. That said I do like the recharging vs battery replacement on the xc200s. Other than that the Garmins are solid.
data.author: Mark Stender

data.text: I bought them last fall when Clever Training closed and they were on clearance. I also have the SPD-SL conversion kit. No issues so far. All the rest of my tech is Garmin so it all works together well.
data.author: Chad Parvin

data.text: ahh, I have wahoo stuff but it should still work well together ü§∑‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è
data.author: Tyler L. Jenicek
Tzroy Furgoosen

data.text: I‚Äôve got two sets(one for me and one for my wife.) no complaints from me other than they need recalibrated if you experience large temp swings in a ride
data.author: Cory Rood

data.text: that can happen in here in the PNW üòÖ Is it hard to recalibrate?
data.author: Tyler L. Jenicek

data.text: it‚Äôs a 15 second process to recal, just need to be aware of it, I‚Äôve gotten in the habit of recalibrating everytime i stop
data.author: Cory Rood

data.text: oh that‚Äôs not bad
data.author: Tyler L. Jenicek

data.text: I‚Äôve got them on my gravel rig. I like them. No issues at all, and power levels match my others pretty consistently
data.author: Jeff Hoskins

data.text: good to know. Thanks!
data.author: Tyler L. Jenicek

data.text: Any issues from peddle strikes?
data.author: Chris Brower

data.text: nope! I‚Äôve had a few with no issues. I‚Äôm also 220 and used on my MTB to check out. No issues with weight either
data.author: Jeff Hoskins

data.text: thanks man. Im a big guy too. Looking for a left side for my aspero but am reluctant as i do have peddle strikes sometimes. Appreciate this!
data.author: Chris Brower

data.text: I got them last Christmas season and I really like them quite a bit. My fist power meter so I can't speak to accuracy but all the reviews I've read say they are very accurate. I've only had one ride. Where calibration was WAY off, I recalibrated when I noti Ed it was way high and I corrected it afterwards so not a big deal. They can be finicky to calibrate but I've found if you spin the pedals on the crankset and spin the pedals on the crankarms it helps wake up both pedals and helps me get calibrated much faster.
data.author: Jonathan Brown

data.text: appreciate the info. Thank you!
data.author: Tyler L. Jenicek

data.text: I got the single sided ones so far no problem. Used them on my gravel bike and on my mountain bike. The other day I slammed a rock with the left pedal (sensor) and nothing happened they keep working
data.author: Fernando Abiud Medina

data.text: sounds like durability isn‚Äôt an issue. Glad it‚Äôs still working

data.text: I actually have 2nd gen Vectors dual that are still working !!! The ones with the pods. I also use those on some gravel rides

data.text: oh nice!
data.author: Tyler L. Jenicek

data.text: I‚Äôm running them on my gravel bike and occasionally MTB. Very happy with them so far. Only glitch I‚Äôve experienced was when I tried to change the crank length in the settings - Garmin Connect wouldn‚Äôt do it (but I assume that‚Äôs just an app error because it usually works fine). I get a lot of pedal strikes on rocks here, just some barely visible scuffs on the pedals so far.

data.text: The Favero hack is also an option but I really don‚Äôt like the exposed pod, and many people apparently have to trim their shoe soles to fit the pod.
data.author: David Watson

data.text: saw these. The battery life seems a bit short but the weight in comparison to garmin is nice!
data.author: Tyler L. Jenicek

data.text: yeeaahhhh. That and the warranty issue kind of have me looking elsewhere
data.author: Tyler L. Jenicek

data.text:
I‚Äôve been running the single sided version on the gravel bike for about a year now. They have been rock solid. Bought them thinking I would swap them back and forth between the MTB and the gravel rig but that hasn‚Äôt really happened. In hind sight, I think I could have saved some dollars and quite a bit of weight going with the Stages crank based power meter https://stagescycling.com/en_us/product/gen-3-stages-power-l-grx-rx810-power-meter. I may still do that if I can find a buyer for the Rally‚Äôs.
GEN 3 STAGES POWER L | GRX RX810 POWER METER
stagescycling.com

data.text: ahhh this is a great option as well!
data.author: Tyler L. Jenicek

data.text: curious - if you're not a racer why use a power meter?
data.author: Chris Summers

data.text: why wear a heart rate monitor?
data.author: Cory Rood

data.text: I don't use any of it. Just ride along. To me all the data spoils a good ride.
data.author: Chris Summers

data.text: congrats, some people like data.
data.author: Cory Rood

data.text: Yeah, and thats why I asked - why do some people like data? I know there are a lot of apps and appliances out there but what are people getting out of it. Maybe I'm missing something. But Thanks for the compliment its always nice to meet nice people with common interests on FB
data.author: Chris Summers

data.text: I‚Äôm interested in the left/right balance and everything else I guess. Ultimately, I just want to improve. Data will help target some things I‚Äôm looking to work on. Totally don‚Äôt race, though. It‚Äôll help be more aware and efficient‚Ä¶at least, I hope!
data.author: Tyler L. Jenicek

data.text: data is a motivator for me to quantify progress and on longer rides I can work towards a power target I know I can sustain for a given timeframe.
data.author: Ted Redmer

data.text: yeah, all that
data.author: Tyler L. Jenicek

data.text: Absolutely brilliant. Particularly if you use other Garmin stuff. Worth the money. Even gone to Garmin Rally‚Äôs for my road bikes from stages and SRM. Accurate and bombproof.

data.text: awesome, thanks for the info!

data.text: I use the spd rally‚Äôs on gravel and Mtb and would like to see a larger platform one come out as I ride gravity enduro w my son too.
data.author: Tony Gerard

data.text: 6k km and a New England season of cyclocross and a mucky winter without a single problem. Engagement isn‚Äôt as good/solid/crisp as XTR pedals but I‚Äôm being picky.

Gravel Power Meter Pedals | Favero Assioma to Xpedo CXR SPD 2 bolt

data.author: Chris Bussiere

data.text: Serious competition üòâ AT 385g for the pair, there‚Äôs nothing lighter. Clears mud better than anything else. Four way entry, and easy exit. You can vary the amount of float and add for differ shoe lug height. The only down side is if you come ‚Äúdown‚Äù on a rock or root the wings that are pointed down can release you cleat. Personally I don‚Äôt find that to be a problem, I‚Äôd rather they released when I didn‚Äôt need it rather than didn‚Äôt release when I wanted it to. If you use flexy shoes you may prefer a platform, but if you use stiff carbon soled shoes not only will will you not need any additional platform, but will be way lighter (shoes & pedals) üêç

data.text: I have a pair, and I like them. I also have the Assioma favarro duo that I‚Äôve converted with Xpedo cyclocross SPDs. I the assioma is lighter, but the design feels like it‚Äôs more vulnerable to damage from pedal strikes. I‚Äôve never damaged them, but it concerns me. The rally seems more durable. Not sure which I would say is better

data.text: My wife and I each have a set. The only issue we‚Äôve had is the battery cap coming off. Hers fell out during a ride and I found mine was loose.
